 For those who don't know about stewart, here is the brief:
 
 Stewart was arrested and charged with (among other things) posession of a machine gun. The machine gun in question was home made. In court, stewarts attorneys argued that since the machine gun in question had never been in interstate commerce, the NFA did not apply to it (remember, the NFA is a tax bill, nothing more). The 9th circuit found that stewart was correct. The DOJ appealed and the appeals court upheld the ruling. It looked like the DOJ was going to let it go, but at the last second filed for certiorari, and now it is up to teh supreme court to decide whether or not to hear the case.
 
 Possible ramifications if the supreme court refuses:
 
 From a practical standpoint, the ruling of the 9th becomes the law of the land. People who live in the 9th district can more or less start building machine guns in their garages and there is not a damn thing the government can do about it.
 
 Possible ramifications if the supreme court hears the case:

 Apparently the real concern is that the ATF, in their haste to make illegal anything that could even remotely be considered a machine gun, ruled that an auto sear is in and of itself a machine gun, whether it is installed in a gun or not.
 
 An autosear is a piece of metal that slips into an AR-15 to make it full auto. It is a U shaped deal with a little bend to it. Your average idiot could make one in about 10 minutes with a pair of tin snips and some pliers. 
 
 Lets say for a minute that the supreme court rules that a machine gun, constructed at home and never having traveled in interstate commerce is not subject to the provisions of the NFA. Now, if the ATF had not been in such a hurry to outlaw anything and everything that could be considered a machine gun, that would still restrict the construction of such weapons to people who are fairly well equipped and posess a fair amount of technical expertise. By ruling that an autosear (or a FA bolt) is in and of itself a machine gun, they have kind of shot themselves in the foot, since either component can be constructed by your average 10th grader.

FYI: Its true many states have their own laws regulating or banning machine guns which arose from an attempt to create a uniform set of state laws (don't ask me when the push came at the state level, bc I don't know). What I do know is that my beloved Commonwealth of Virginia passed the template of what became styled as the "Uniform Machine Gun Act," and you can find it here http://legis.state.va.us/Laws/CodeofVa.htm. If you want to see how machine guns are defined and regulated in Va, then indiviudally search these code sections: 18.2-288 (definitions) 18.2-289 (use of MG for crime of violence) 18.2-290 (use of MG for aggressive purpose) 18.2-291 (what constitutes aggressive purpose, including presumption that possession is for aggressive purpose IF empty or loaded shells for the MG are found with it or in close proximity), 18.2-292 (presence of MG = prima facie evidence of use) 18.2-293 (What UMG act does not apply to, like LE and military possession) 18.2-293.1 (what UMG act does not prohibit, including C&R possession) 18.2-294 (manufacturer/dealer registration/inspection) 18.2-295 (registration of MGs) 18.2-296 (search warrants for MGs).
 
 These laws may OR MAY NOT be similar to laws in your state. Most state legislatures now maintain web pages with searchable state code databases.

It is an element of proof of a particular crime, and not a crime itself, to possess ammunition or spent shell casings which can/could have been fired in the machinegun.  You're also correct about little, if any, surfacing of unregistered Class 3 weapons within conventional society. All class 3 receivers and bolts including relics and curios were subjected to registration in 1986. They're so closely monitored that the BATFE knows where each and every one is located at any given minute. The tax process, the actual control point, takes about 90-days for the transfer of any class 3 weapon, which documents the seller, the licensed class 3 selling transfer agent, the licensed receiving class 3 transfer agent and the buyer. Add in the cost of most class 3 pieces, which puts them out of reach for the average person, and control is virtually absolute. 
 
 Which created a thriving black market with urban gangs, the dope crowd (not to combat authorities but competitors), survivalists and those people who bend laws for enjoyment as eager buyers of cheap, smuggled and stolen class three weapons.
